Award.AwardTitle: ATD: Collaborative Research: Algorithms and Data for High-Frequency, Real-Time Anomaly Detection
Award.AbstractNarration:
The rapidly burgeoning amount of digital data from Internet and mobile-enabled communications can offer low-cost and high-resolution views into human behavior across areas such as health and socio-economics. Personally-generated data from Internet and mobile-connected sources offer unique insight, capturing aspects of human behavior that would be taxing or impossible to quantify through other data sources. Moreover, the data is often available in real time and can be linked to specific locations. This research project addresses the statistical challenges inherent in using such unstructured spatio-temporal data sets for detection of anomalous events.

Such data requires new statistical approaches to pre-process and extract forms from the data that can reliably be used for event detection. Further, the continuous nature of the data means that what constitutes anomalous behavior depends on the time-scale and on the type of underlying event. This project aims to develop 1) approaches for generating relevant features from social media data that account for the observational nature of the data and can be used in spatio-temporal models of real-world behavior and 2) a new multi-scale approach to modeling dependence structures that uses new information to continuously refine the model and accurately assess anomalies. The approach in this project is both suited to and harnesses the continuous and observational nature of social media data. The research will be validated on empirical data sets, demonstrating practical utility. It is anticipated that the results will be applicable to further the use of publicly-available geospatial data sources and understand human dynamics that are not measurable through other means.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our work develops the next generation of mathematical and statistical algorithms to identify unusual behavior in communications data (either device-to-device networks or personal communications like social media). The methods we propose reduce the computation time over existing approaches and identify unusual behavior more quickly, allowing cybersecurity experts to investigate and, if necessary, take action.

In terms of intellectual merit, we develop statistical models that produce a more detailed characterization of typical behavior. One common strategy to detect unusual behavior is to build a model that describes how people/devices typically act and then compare the current behavior to that baseline. A nuanced baseline is important because if the method flags too many events as unusual that aren't actually harmful then cybersecurity professionals investigating those events will spend all of their time looking into events that pose no threat rather than cases of potential hacking or cyberattacks. Our work develops a baseline model that considers how groups of individuals/devices typically interact with one-another, rather than simply one person or device at a time. The attached image shows that this approach improves detection using data from a communications network in a large organization. The left plot shows the existing state of the art and the right shows our approach. Each point in the plot is a potentially anomalous event with the horizontal axis being the score from our method. The events are listed in order, so a cybersecurity professional using the method would start investigating the event at the top of the vertical axis and work down. In these data there is a known attack, represented by the red line. Using the existing method an investigator would need to comb through nearly twice as many events before finding the true cybersecurity threat as with the approach developed for this project.

For broader impacts, we develop a number of computational tools that apply in settings outside of our proposed domain. Specifically, we derive methods that can parse large amounts streaming data with minimal reduction in accuracy. Our methods are particularly useful for data that are highly dependent (e.g. multiple observations on the same person or cases where people influence one-another's behavior).


Last Modified: 02/19/2021
Modified by: Tyler Mccormick

One common strategy to detect unusual behavior is to build a model that describes how people/devices typically act and then compare the current behavior to that baseline. A nuanced baseline is important because if the method flags too many events as unusual that aren't actually harmful then cybersecurity professionals investigating those events will spend all of their time looking into events that pose no threat rather than cases of potential hacking or cyberattacks. Our work develops a baseline model that considers how groups of individuals/devices typically interact with one-another, rather than simply one person or device at a time. The events are listed in order, so a cybersecurity professional using the method would start investigating the event at the top of the vertical axis and work down.
